the state periodically distributed grain free to the populace; this must have been stored in a granary (Bloch 1942: 128)
olive and grape orchards
mules or donkeys used for carrying cargo from Ostia to Rome
oxen for pulling plows (Bloch 1942: 122); for drawing wagons (Fowler 1933: 55)
Roman streets were winding and twisting (Carcopino 1956: 53); provincial towns had grid plan (Singer et al. 1957: 276-280)
four districts, each with an edile in charge (Bloch 1942: 52); Augustus divided Rome into 14 regions (Carcopino 1942: 23)

5% or 10% inheritance tax (Bloch 1942: 133)

shoemakers; bakers
porters, mule drivers

there were many at pompei in 79 A.D. – dyers, bakers, gold smiths, fruiterers, green-grocers, wood merchants, cartwrights, fishermen, husbandmen, muleteers, cooks, fullers, etc. (Yaggy and Haines 1882: 44); smiths and potters (Fowler 1933: 54); shoemakers guild (Fowler 1933: 53)
state produced salt; first sold it at cost, later made a fancy profit on it. During Imperial times, the mines were operated by the Emperor for his personal property (Bloch 1942: 132-133)
“labourers necessary for the maintenance of her buildings and monuments”

?; Roman soldiers, while not engaged in a campaign, were assigned tasks for the state, such as road building, digging canals, making ships. Most state buildings in the province were built with this type of labor; ediles were in charge of calling up men for the crovée – pre-Imperial?
cattle originally; later pieces of copper, with state seal to guarantee purity (Bloch 1942: 124)

copper coins, in various denominations; silver and later gold coins; In 15 A.D. it was decided that coining of gold and silver coins was to be the sole prerogative of the Emperor, and coining of copper coins of the senate
by the state (Bloch 1942: 133)
vinarii
cereal market (Bloch 1942: 51)
not conclusive

ediles supervised weights and measures used in commerce (Bloch 1942: 121); 4% tax on sale of slaves; supervised purity of metals (copper) used as media of exchange (Bloch 1942: 124); ediles prevented price-fixing and speculation (Bloch 1942: 52); slavemarkets supervised (Fowler 1933: 211)
“accounts kept by the banker” (Fowler 1933: 81); “libros de contabilidad” (Bloch 1942: 118)
censors recorded the wealth of all citizens during census

master coinmaker, equivalent to director of mint (Bloch 1942: 126); cuestors had this function (Bloch 1942: 56); aerarium, state treasury, located in Rome; silver from mines in Spain came here except for that paid out as booty to soldiers (Fowler 1933: 20,66-67); The fiscus, the state treasury under the Emperor, was under his control and administered by officials (procuratores) appointed by him (Bloch 1942: 139)
should be – [but the original plus is not crossed off]

conquered land given to citizens to occupy and farm; 10% of cereals and 20% of wine and oil paid as tax to the state (Bloch 1942: 132,134); not until the decadence of the empire did Italian property owners have to pay taxes as the inhabitants of the provinces had (Bloch 1942: 131); Sicily, Asia, and other provinces paid their taxes in the form of a tithe (Fowler 1933: 72)

“in 167 B.C. after the second Macedonian War, the tributum or property tax was no longer imposed upon all citizens” (Fowler 1933: 67); those unfit (ineligible) for military service, widows and orphans paid a tax (Bloch 1942: 133); general and direct taxation imposed during empire based on ability to pay (Bloch 1942: 134)

(+); during Republican times the job of tax collector (publicani) was let out to private entrepreneurs, who guaranteed the state a certain amount; But under Empire taxes perhaps collected by officials
clientes were something like this
a borrower of money could make security of his person (Fowler 1933: 56, Bloch 1942: 112); a father could sell his son into slaver (Bloch 1942: 111-112)

freemen wore pointed hat (pileus)  and short hair(Bloch 1942: 107), which slaves did not (Bloch 1942: 180); shoes different according to rank and occupation (Fowler 1933: 53); purple robes for some officials (Bloch 1942: 48)
the above would seem to qualify; ediles fined persons who violated sumptuary laws
magnificent villas
have estates (Fowler 1933: 47); latifundia of South Italy (Fowler 1933: 131)
exempt from military service, if they wanted, but taxed to support army
slaves (Fowler 1933: 47)
?; but the lower classes were admitted also (Bloch 1942: 157-158); senators sat in seats of honor (Bloch 1942: 66)
?; lower classes could attend too
deceased dressed in finest clothes, with insignia of highest office reached, and with utensils, arms and jewelry
Cicero thought of erecting a tomb to the memory of his daughter, Tullia; a fanum was a shrine to the memory of a person
does Senate qualify?
perhaps after he was appointed this was so
?; “an electoral district of an urban tribe”
“prefect of the city”; an edile was in charge of each of 4 districts of Rome
public officials received no pay
when new territories conquered, colonists given land by state (Bloch 1942: 132)
elected by the senate
?; victorious ? general could bestow Roman citizenship of persons of newly conquered territory; political citizenship
Augustus took over the function of appointing priests
?; slaves <- personal?
praetorian guard; Emperor was only person who could have such; formerly (Republican times) generals had them too
first the laurel crown, later the Helios (sol victrix), and later still (after Antoninus Pius) the aureola (nimbus)
(+); aes signatum, seal of bull (usually) stamped on copper to guarantee purity for commercial exchange
or take oath of office (Fowler 1933: 21); censors swore to dispense justice impartially (Bloch 1942: 48,60)
(-); emperor was a member of one of the priestly groups

a cult of the person of the Emperor developed; “deification by apotheosis did not occur in Rome except after the death of the Emperor. Only at the end of the third century did the emperors dare to call themselves gods during their lifetime”; there were cults to living emperor in the Provinces but not in Rome

“after his death [Julius Caesar] was duly canonised as Divus, and had a temple erected to him”; “there cannot be a doubt that the ordinary Roman believed in the godhood of Julius” (Fowler 1933: 348); see [trait] No. 183

Italy considered a confederacy of states (although Rome had vanquished them all) and confederate state (socii) were expected to contribute a stipulated number of soldiers during war time. Home state paid them; Rome housed and provisioned them (Bloch 1942: 95)
generals could make such treaties

(+); State [underlined] - x; upper classes [underlined] - ?; schools which lesser officials had to attend to be eligible for office (Bloch 1942: 57); schoolmasters paid by parent of students, not by state (Carcopino 1956: 109); schools of rhetoric, most famous ones being in Athens and Rhodes, to which scions of upper class families, seeking higher education, might go. Not operated by the state (Bloch 1942: 183)
in late Republican times a murderer or thief might be killed by his intended victim if caught red-handed (Fowler 1933: 58)
courts for the trials of crimes of violence introduced by Sulla
court of cassation; decision of an edile could be appealed to a popular tribunal – but edile not a court, or are they?
reviewed decisions of lower court and was a court of last instance
Emperor did so; (Vestal Virgins could, if they happened on one on the streets of Rome!)
Emperors promulgated edicts and laws, abolished some offices, established new ones

members of the Senate could waive application of certain laws to its own members (Fowler 1933: 125); members of lower class had no right to appeal in a convictions in a criminal case; senators, “caballeros”, conspicuous citizens did” (Bloch 1942: 116)
draft dodging
the emperor got the bulk of this
whipping for draft dodging; whipping “antiguamente”
draft dodging
apparently abrogated at some time; for lese majesty during Imperial times
four companies of gendarmes, cohortes urbanae [fire department, too] (Bloch 1942: 97); Augustus introduced a well-organized system of police (Fowler 1933: 59)
for draft dodging (Bloch 1942: 88); prisons (Bloch (1942: 57); slave prison (Fowler 1933: 209)
gold taken by general after successful campaigns
head of the cavalry
centurions [underlined], optio, signifer
cavalry was such
provincials and freed slaves recruited; slingers from Balearic Islands, bowmen from Crete, cavalry from Spain, etc.
5000 enemies killed in battle became prerequisite for awarding a triumph to a general
Romans apparently invented the hollow square for use against cavalry attacks
banner, under which oath of allegiance taken; silver eagle but each legion had one, formerly used sticks with hay, animal figures
artillery
often became nucleus of a town, however
many siege weapons, including battering ram, with iron point shaped like a ram’s head, terraplanes[?], built to height of enemy walls, siege towers, etc.
catapultae, which fired darts in a straight line, and ballistae, which hurled stones at a 45 degree angle
a number of different kinds awarded

retired veterans who had served the prescribed 20 yrs. in the infantry and 10 yrs. in the cavalry received an allotment of land; Caesar gave out money; Republican generals coined money in the field, gave some to troops
by virtue of the fact that they were given grants of land centurions sometimes rose to the class of knight; + Hierarchy of military unit; + Emblems of command
not regularly, in one sense, but apparently done at the temple of Jupiter during the “triumph” of a victorious general; see [trait] no. 254
Ptolemy Auletes, King of Egypt, apparently retained in power
Mars
Diana patroness of the plebs; Vesta was the patron deity of bakers

harvest god; Jupiter, Juno, Vulcan, Flora, Vesta, Diana, Ceres, Venus, Apollo
Jupiter (Fowler 1933: 21); called Optimus Maximus (Fowler 1933: 337); monotheism was being approached (Fowler 1933: 338)

there were statues of Jupiter, Juno, Minerva, etc. (Fowler 1933: 339); Sulla “always carried a small image of Apollo, which he kissed from time to time, and to which he prayed silently in moments of danger” (Fowler 1933: 345)

hecatomb – the sacrifice of 100 white bulls during triumphal reception of victorious general (Bloch 1942: 106); for a minor triumph a general sacrificed a sheep (Bloch 1942: 108); sacrificing black sheep to manes (spirits of the dead) (Fowler 1933: 343)

the more notable war prisoners were sacrificed on the day a conquering general was given his triumphal reception; was it to gods? Yes, done at Jupiter’s temple; after the battle of Cannas, two Greeks were buried alive
Roman legions carried altars with them on which sacrifices (?) were made for good fortune in war (Bloch 1942: 99); house altar (Yaggy and Haines 1882: 49)
pontifexes
appointed by the Emperor; pontifex maximus did this until the function was taken by the Emperor Augustus
interpreters of auguries; sacrificial priests (cultarii); augurs, haruspices, flamines, etc.; war priests
of Diana; of Mars; Jupiter
owned land (Bloch 1942: 145); “statues and other temple property” (Fowler 1933: 321)
Vestal virgins (Fowler 1933: 19); served for 30 years (Bloch 1942: 149)
“sacerdotal office was especially desired because it permitted the exercise of political influence”; also certain legal authority
